Over time, rent control acts as a buffer against the natural inflation of housing costs, which often outpaces wage growth. This is especially critical in urban centers where housing demand is high and supply is constrained. When lower- and middle-income families are able to stay in their communities, the entire neighborhood benefits from continuity, local business stability, and stronger social networks.
